== Contents == 
<wiki:toc max_depth="5" />

== Goals == 
  * Become familiar with basic features of GUARDD



== Requirements ==
  # 60-90 min
  # Matlab software [http://www.mathworks.com/ Mathworks]
  # GUARDD program [http://code.google.com/p/guardd/downloads/list download]
    # Matlab .m and .fig files
  # Tutorial files for this example [http://code.google.com/p/guardd/downloads/list download]
    # tutorial-data/
      # LIST DATA FILES
    # tutorial-figures/
      # Screen capture images linked within this tutorial
      # tutorial-output/
      # Output figures for some plots produced during tutorial 


== General notes ==  
  # GUARDD utilizes multiple GUI windows (may need to be resized)
    # Higher monitor resolution helps (1024x768 minimum)
  # GUARDD main window *must remain open* (it controls other GUI elements) [Figure] 
  # Check Matlab command window for additional output
  # GUARDD is sometimes slow. Turn on CPU monitor to see when program is processing
    # *Win*: Ctrl+Alt+Del, click _Task Manager_
    # *Mac*: ?    
  # "Tooltips" are revealed by hovering mouse cursor over buttons, tables, etc.

== Notation ==  
  * NMR = Nuclear Magnetic Resonance
  * GUARDD = Graphical User-friendly Analysis of Relaxation Dispersion Data
  * RD = Relaxation Disperion
  * 4-5 parameters are required to fit a single RD curve
    # Δω,,H,, = Δω,,H,,, = ^1^H chemical shift difference between states A and B (ppm, rad/s, Hz) - *MQ only*
    # Δω,,X,, = Δω,,X,,, = ^A^X chemical shift difference between states A and B (ppm, rad/s, Hz)
    # P,,A,, = Population fraction of A state (fraction, %)
    # k,,ex,, = k,,A,, + k,,B,, = Total exchange rate between states (/s)
    # R,,2,,^0^ = Transverse relaxation rate in the absence of exchange (Hz)
  * Exchange kinetics can be described as follows
    * k,,A,, = Rate of exchange from A->B
    * k,,B,, = Rate of exchange from B->A
    * Method A - No constraint on rate analysis
      * Define P,,A,, and k,,ex,, at each temperature
    * Method B - Constrain rate analysis via ΔH and E,,AB,,
      * Define P,,A,, and k,,ex,, at a single temperature, T,,0,,
      * Define ΔH for temperature-dependence of P,,A,, (vant Hoff)
      * Define E,,AB,, for temperature-dependence of k,,A,, and, using ΔH, k,,B,, (Arrhenius)
  * SQ = Single Quantum (signal detected in NMR)
    * *Note*: SQ curves that pulse on ^A^X nucleus are sensitive _only_ to Δω,,X,, (Δω,,H,, is fixed to zero)
  * MQ = Multiple Quantum (signal detected in NMR)
    * *Note*: MQ RD curves are sensitive to _both_ Δω,,H,, and Δω,,X,,

  * GUI = Graphical User Interface  
  * <u>Underlined</u> items are GUARDD window titles
  * *Boldface* items are commands (buttons, menus) and important points

  * MC = Monte Carlo (randomization method used here for error analysis)
  * Chi2 = χ^2^ = Goodness of fit metric (smaller value indicates better fit)
    * Statistics χ^2^ and SSE are considered equivalent in this tutorial (see [Manual])  

== Tutorial ==

=== Download and unpack files ===
  # Download files [http://code.google.com/p/guardd/downloads/list download]
  # Unpack files
    # E.g., "/home/user/Desktop/" or "C:\My_Favorite_Folder\"
  # Ensure proper directory structure
    # GUARDD-YYYY-MM-DD/	(*Note*: {{{YYYY-MM-DD}}} codes for the date (e.g., {{{2011-06-08}}}))
      # tutorial/
      # (Many .m files)
      # (Many .fig files)

=== Start GUARDD ===
  # Start *Matlab*  
  # Open Matlab command window: *Desktop...Command Window*
  # Navigate to GUARDD/ directory and start program
    # <u>Matlab command window</u>: {{{cd 'c:\My_Favorite_Folder\GUARDD--YYYY-MM-DD\'}}}
    # *Note*: {{{YYYY-MM-DD}}} is replaced by the date corresponding to the GUARDD version (e.g., {{{2011-06-08}}})_
    # <u>Matlab command window</u>: {{{GUARDD}}}
  # *Important*: Main window must remain open (it controls all other GUI windows)
  # Check Matlab command window for additional output

<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--01.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--01.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a>

=== Load data ===
  * *Goal*: _Get RD data into the program for analysis_
  * *Tip*: _A variety of input types are available (see [Manual])_

  # <u>Main</u>
    # *Input...Data manager...*
  # <u>Data Manager</u>
    # *Input...Script...*
      # _tutorial/data/GUARDD-Data-ApoTRAP-Kleckner.txt_
    # *Input...Sequence...*
      # _tutorial/data/TRAP-Ste-A26I-AAseq.txt_
  # 14 datasets loaded    
    # 600 and 800 MHz
    # 25, 32, and 37^o^C
    # SQ and MQ coherence

<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--02.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--02.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a>

=== Create groups for fitting ===
  * *Goal*: _Aggregate RD curves from the same NMR signal (assignment) for group fitting_
  * *Details*: Read more in the [Manual]
  [http://guardd.googlecode.com/files/figure-data_management.png image]

  # <u>Data Manager</u>    
    # *Group...Generate from subset of data...*
  # <u>Create Groups</u>
    # Make groups only for Ile residues at 25^o^C
      # Check _Residue_
      # Type _Ile_
      # Check _TempC_
      # Type _25_
    # Click *Generate groups*
  # <u>Data Manager</u>
    # *Group...Generate from subset of data...*
  # <u>Create Groups</u>
    # Make groups only for index 22
      # Check _Residue_
      # Type _22_
    # Click *Generate groups*
  # <u>Data Manager</u>
    # *Group...Sort groups*
  # Close the <u>Data Manager</u> window

<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--03.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--03.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a>

=== Select residues with exchange ===
  * *Goal*: _Determine which groups exhibit flexibility, and therefore warrant further analysis_  
  * *Details*: Read more in the [Manual]

  # <u>Main</u>
    # Click *Refresh* to show loaded groups
    # Use *<* and *>* to cycle through groups
    # Check *Exch?* if the data are not horizontal (i.e., R,,ex,, > 0)
      # *Note*: all residues exhibit exchange except Ile 61δ,,1,, and Ile 68δ,,1,,

<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--04.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--04.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a>

=== Fit simple group manually ===
  * *Goal*: _Use <u>Fit RD</u> window to manually fit one group_
    * _Determine optimal P,,A,,, and k,,ex,,, at each temperature (x1) -> propagate to all curves in group_
    * _Determine optimal Δω,,H,,, Δω,,X,,, for each curveset (x1) -> propagated to all curves in curveset_
    * _Determine and R,,2,,^0^ for each curve (x4)_
  * *Goal*: _Demonstrate basic fitting options (Simulate vs. Optimize, Individual vs. Grid)_
  * *Details*: Read more in the [Manual]

  # <u>Main</u>
    # Select _Ile 26_
    # Check *Fit dispersion*
    # Click *Update displays*
  # <u>Fit RD</u>
    # _Contains 6 panels for sequential fitting tasks_
    # (1a) Procedure: *Individual*
    # (1b) Task: *Simulate*
    # (2) Individual initial conditions: (Leave default)
      # *Note*: Often, one may change starting P,,A,,, k,,ex,,, Δω,,H,,, and Δω,,X,,
    # Click *Go!* (1-5 sec)
      # Note that these initial conditions are reasonable (fit is somewhat close to data)
    # (1b) Task: *Optimize fit*
    # Click *Go!* (5-30 sec)
    # (3) Select and view fit results
      # There are three fits to data: NoEx, Sim-1, and Fit-1
      # Select each at a time, and note that _Sim-1_ is the best (lines go through data in panel (4))
      # Select _Sim-1_
      # Click *Set best fit*
    # (6) Designate which parameters are OK
      # Check *Best fit is OK*
      # Click *All*
      # *Note*: In general, one should more carefully check if the best fit is OK (see [Manual])


<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--05.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--05.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a> 


  * *Goal*: _If unsure about which initial conditions to use, the grid search fits multiple times with different initial conditions_
      # (1a) Procedure: *Grid search*
      # Use a relatively small grid, for the tutorial

|| 		|| *dwH(ppm)*	|| *dwX(ppm)*	|| *PA0(%)*	|| *kex0(/s)*	||
|| *Min* 	|| 0.01  	|| 0.1  	|| 80  		|| 500  	||
|| *Max* 	|| 0.1  	|| 3.00  	|| 99.9  	|| 3000  	||
|| *Steps*	|| 1  		|| 2  		|| 2  		|| 3  		||

      # Click *Save*
      # (1b): Task: *Optimize fit*
      # Click *Go!* (5-10 sec/fit x 12 fits = 60-120 sec)
      # (3) Select and view fit results
	# The Fit-G result is the best fit (lowest χ^2^) out of all the fits in the grid search      
      # (6) Designate which parameters are OK
	# Click *All*
      # *Note*: _Becuase this the initial conditions were appropriate (above), it yields the same best fit as the 12 starting points from the grid search_
      # *Note*: _The grid search can demonstrate a successful fit, if the fit is *insensitive* to inital conditions_

<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--06.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--06.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a> 

=== Fit multi-temperature group manually ===
  * *Goal*: _Use <u>Fit RD</u> window to manually fit one group acquired at multiple temperatures_
    * _Determine optimal P,,A,,, and k,,ex,,, at each temperature (x3) via two methods (A and B) -> propagate to all curves in group_
    * _Determine optimal Δω,,H,,, Δω,,X,,, for each curveset (x1) -> propagated to all curves in curveset_
    * _Determine and R,,2,,^0^ for each curve (x10)_
  * *Goal*: _Demonstrate multi-temperature fitting options_
    * Method A (No rate constraint): _Determine optimal P,,A,, and k,,ex,, at each temperature_
    * Method B (Impose rate constraint): _Determine optimal P,,A,, and k,,ex,, at some temperature T,,0,,, with ΔH and E,,AB,, to determine P,,A,, and k,,ex,, at an arbitrary temperature_
  
  * *Details*: Read more in the [Manual]

  # <u>Main</u>
    # Select _Leu 22delta1_
    # Check *Fit dispersion*
    # Click *Update displays*
  # <u>Fit RD</u>
    # Fit without rate constraints
    # (1a) Procedure: *Individual*
    # (1b) Task: *Simulate*
    # Uncheck *Constrain Rates*
    # (2) Individual initial conditions

|| *Temp(C)* 	|| *PA(%)*	|| *kex(/s)*	||
|| 25		|| 95		|| 1000		||
|| 32		|| 96		|| 1200		||
|| 37		|| 97		|| 1500		||

|| *Curveset*	|| *dwH(ppm)*	|| *dwX(ppm)*	||
|| Leu 22\delta1|| 0.1		|| 1		||

    # Click *Go!* (1-5 sec)
      # Note that these initial conditions are reasonable (fit is somewhat close to data)
    # (1b) Task: *Optimize fit*
    # Click *Go!* (5-30 sec)

    # (3) Select Fit-1`[--]` fit result
      # Click *Set as best fit*
    # (6) Designate that all parameters are OK
      # Check *Best fit is OK*
      # Click *All*

<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--07.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--07.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a> 


    # Fit with rate constraints
    # (1a) Procedure: *Individual*
    # (1b) Task: *Simulate*
    # Check *Constrain Rates*
    # (2) Individual initial conditions
      
|| *T0(C)*	|| *PA0(%)*	|| *kex0(/s)*	|| *dH(kcal/mol)*	|| *Eab(kcal/mol)*	||
|| 25		|| 95		|| 1000		|| -5			|| 1			||

|| *Curveset*	|| *dwH(ppm)*	|| *dwX(ppm)*	||
|| Leu 22\delta1|| 0.1		|| 1		||

    # Click *Go!* (1-5 sec)
      # Note that these initial conditions are reasonable (fit is somewhat close to data)
    # (1b) Task: *Optimize fit*
    # Click *Go!* (5-30 sec)

    # (3) Select Fit-1`[CR]` fit result
      # Click *Set as best fit*
    # (6) Designate that all parameters are OK
      # Check *Best fit is OK*
      # Click *All*

<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--08.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--08.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a> 

  * *Goal*: _Use <u>Rates</u> window to examine temperature-dependence of rates (vant Hoff and Arrenius)_
  # <u>Main</u>
    # Select _Leu 22delta1_
    # Check *Display rates*
    # Click *Update displays*
  # <u>Rates</u>
    # Select fit: *`Fit-1[--]`*
      # The rates in this fit are independently determined for each temperature
      # ΔH, E,,AB,,, and E,,BA,, are extracted from the slopes
    # Select fit: *`Fit-1[CR]`*
      # The rates are constrained to lie along the line with slope ΔH, E,,AB,,, or E,,BA,, 
    # Close <u>Rates</u>
  # <u>Main</u>
    # Uncheck *Dsplay rates*

<a href="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--09.png"> <img src="http://web.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/~ikleckne/GUARDD-tutorial/tutorial-GUARDD-2011.06.09--09.png" alt="[UNLOADED IMAGE]" width="200"> </img> </a> 

=== Fit multi-curveset, multi-temperature group manually ===   
  * *Goal*: _Use <u>Data Manager</u> to create a group with multiple curvesets_
  # <u>Main</u>
    # *Input...Data manager...*
  # <u>Data Manager</u>
    # Create a new group for Leu 22
      # Click *New* in the panel _Groups for fitting_
      # Table on right, enter group *name*: _Leu 22_
      # Table on right, enter group *index*: _22_
      # Click *Save* in the panel _Groups for fitting_
    # Add two curvesets to this new group
      # Select group *Leu 22\delta1*
      # Select curveset *Leu 22\delta1*
      # Click *Copy to group*
      # <u>Select Group</u>
      # Select group *Leu 22*
      # Click *Select*
      # (Repeat this process with the second curveset, *Leu 22\delta2*)
    # *Group...Sort groups...*
    # Make sure that group _Leu 22_ contains two curvesets: _Cp(Leu 22\delta1)_ and _Cp(Leu 22\delta2)_
    # Close <u>Data Manager</u>

=== Select best fit from grid search ===
  * *Goal*: _Assess the extent to which fitting is sensitive to initial conditions_
  * *Details*: Read more in the [Manual]


=== Compute errors with Monte Carlo ===
  * *Goal*: _Assess the extent to which fitting is sensitive to noise in the data_
  * *Details*: Read more in the [Manual]

=== Determine which parameters are OK ===
  * *Goal*: _Often, some parameters cannot be determined via fitting (e.g., fast exchange precludes knowledge of P,,A,, and Δω)_
  * *Goal*: _Only use fitted parameters which are trustworthy_
  # Check exchange-timescale parameter α
  # Check sensitivity of fit to initial conditions (grid search)
  # Check sensitivity of fit to errors in data (Monte Carlo errors)

  

=== View results via display cluster ===
  * *Goal*: _Aggregate and output any/all results for dissemination_

  * *Goal*: _Load session of pre-fit data for display_
  # <u>Main</u>
    # *Input...Load session...* (1-30 sec)
      # _tutorial/data/GUARDD-Session-Tutorial.mat_

  * *Goal*: _Create two display groups to compare different fiting constraints_  
  # <u>Main</u>
    # *Output...Group display...*
  # <u>Groups</u>
    # Click *New*
    # Set *name*: Isolated fits
    # Click *Save*
    # Panel _All Groups_, select all groups _except_ Leu 22
    # Click *Add*
    # Click *New*
    # Set *name*: Group fits
    # Set _RGB_ to 1 0 0 (for the color Red)
    # Panel _All Groups_, select _only_ Leu 22
    # Click *Add*

  * *Goal*: _Compare individual fits from each NMR probe to form candidate groups, identify outliers, etc._
  # <u>Groups</u>
    # Panel _Display settings_
    # Select plot type: _Kinetic rate (25C)_
      # *Note*: Differences in k,,A,,, k,,B,, values indicates the extent of site-specific motion in the protein_
      # *Note*: Global fit for Leu 22 (red) is close to both individual fits for Leu 22δ_1 and Leu 22δ_2 (blue)
    # Select plot type: _Custom_
      # X-Axis: *Residue*
      # Y-Axis: *dwX_ppm* or *kex* or *alpha* or *Rex*

=== Export data and groups ===
  * *Goal*: _Aggregate and output results for dissemination_

  # <u>Main</u>
    # *Input...Data manager...*
  # <u>Data Manager</u>
    # *Output...Datasets...*
      # Copy of all imported datasets
    # *Output...Groups...*
      # Contains all groups, curvesets, and curves created for analysis

=== Perform batch task ===
  * *Goal*: _Fit several groups sequentially to obviate need for user input_

  # <u>Main</u>
    # *Analysis...Batch task...*
  # <u>Batch</u>
    # Select groups for analysis    
    # Specify the task
      # Grid search: *Optimize*
      # Constrain rates: *Unchecked*
      # Errors: *Unchecked*
    # Specify grid search limits

|| 		|| *dwH(ppm)*	|| *dwX(ppm)*	|| *PA0(%)*	|| *kex0(/s)*	||
|| *Min* 	|| 0.01  	|| 0.1  	|| 80  		|| 500  	||
|| *Max* 	|| 0.1  	|| 3.00  	|| 99.9  	|| 3000  	||
|| *Steps*	|| 1  		|| 2  		|| 2  		|| 3  		||

    # Click *Save to Selected*
    # Click *Go!*
      # Takes ~18 min at 10 sec/step
